pages.title: Jaguar
pages.text: The jaguar is the largest cat species in the New World and the third largest in the world. The jaguar (Panthera onca) is a large felid species and the only extant member of the genus Panthera native to the Americas. It ranges across a variety of forested and open terrains, but its preferred habitat is tropical and subtropical moist broadleaf forest, swamps, and wooded regions. The jaguar enjoys swimming and is largely a solitary, opportunistic, stalk-and-ambush predator at the top of the food chain. While international trade in jaguars or their body parts is prohibited, the cat is still frequently killed, particularly in conflicts with ranchers and farmers in South America. The jaguar has developed an exceptionally powerful bite, even relative to the other big cats. Though there are single cats now living within Arizona, the species has largely been extirpated from the United States since the early 20th century.
